instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
Hi, i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a with loads of corrosion. Theres no green light and  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is not present.

Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7121</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R5250</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5251</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7103</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C2453</CAPACITOR>, and <TRANSISTOR>Q2815</TRANSISTOR>

Diode mode on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0, but nothing seems to be getting warm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
Do you get 14V at both 6 & 8 pins?
Check/replace <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>/96; <CAPACITOR>C6995</CAPACITOR> can be removed.
Post first EXACT diode mode to ground at L6995; not sure if you meant 000, or OL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
Yes, 14v at both pins. 

<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>/96 are looking good and resistances are 127kohms. Removed <CAPACITOR>C6995</CAPACITOR>

L6995 diode mode: 0.000

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
So you have short to ground at <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>; very good reason for NO voltage.
Lift L6995 and see where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
Removed L6995. 

Pin 2 is 0.002 now

Pin 1 is 0.237

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no green light.
threads.message:
Then use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V, no more than 4V.
